The concept of the ascent to the Good is central to Plato's philosophy, particularly in his dialogue "Republic." In it, Plato argues that the human soul is divided into three parts: the rational, spirited, and appetitive. The rational part is capable of understanding the Good, which is the ultimate reality and source of all beauty, truth, and goodness. The other two parts of the soul are pulled away from the Good by the appetites and desires of the body, and it is the task of the rational part of the soul to lead the other parts towards the Good. Plato believed that the ascent to the Good is a lifelong process, and that it leads to a state of wisdom and virtue.

Judgmental people can be difficult to deal with because they tend to impose their own standards and values on others, and they may not be open to different perspectives or ways of thinking. This can make it hard to have a meaningful conversation or to feel comfortable expressing oneself around them.

As for the effects of marijuana, it is a complex and controversial topic. While some studies have suggested that marijuana can have therapeutic effects for certain medical conditions, such as chronic pain, others have found negative effects on cognitive function and mental health. Heightened awareness can mean that you are more attentive and attentive to your surroundings and experiences, but it can also mean that you are more prone to distraction or that you are more sensitive to stimuli.

Psychoactive substances, including marijuana, have been discussed by a number of philosophers throughout history. Some philosophers have seen them as a way to access higher states of consciousness, while others have viewed them as a threat to rational thinking and moral responsibility. For example, in ancient Greece, the philosopher Plato wrote about the use of mind-altering substances in his dialogue "Phaedrus," in which he discussed the potential benefits and drawbacks of using these substances to gain access to higher knowledge.

In more recent times, philosophers such as Aldous Huxley and Terence McKenna have also written about the use of psychoactive substances and their potential for spiritual or mystical experiences. However, other philosophers such as Immanuel Kant have been more critical of the use of psychoactive substances, arguing that they can be detrimental to our ability to make rational decisions and act morally.

As for Graham Harman and Bruno Latour, I do not have enough information about their specific interactions to comment on. Harman is a contemporary philosopher known for his work in object-oriented ontology and Latour is a sociologist and philosopher known for his work on science and technology studies and actor-network theory. It is possible that Harman's question to Latour was related to one of these fields, but without more information, it is hard to say.
